skill.name: code-style-enforcer
skill.description: Analyzes code for style consistency and applies project-specific formatting conventions beyond what linters catch. Use when reviewing code, ensuring style consistency, or when user requests code style improvements.
skill.summary: Analyzes code for style consistency and applies project-specific formatting conventions beyond what ...
skill.author: CrazyDubya

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only instructional documentation. No executable code, no network calls, no file system modifications beyond analysis scope. Uses Read, Grep, Glob tools to analyze project code patterns and provide style recommendations.

content.value_statement: Codebases often drift from consistent style over time. This skill detects style inconsistencies, identifies project-specific conventions, and provides actionable recommendations to maintain code quality.
actual_capabilities: Analyze existing code patterns and conventions
Identify naming, organization, and formatting issues
limitations: Does not modify code files directly
Does not install or configure linting tools
Does not analyze runtime behavior or bugs
Relies on project having existing code to reference

use_cases.title: Team Style Standards
use_cases.description: Ensure all contributors follow the same conventions across the codebase

use_cases.title: Pre-commit Checks
use_cases.description: Review code for style issues before merging pull requests

use_cases.title: Onboarding Help
use_cases.description: Learn project conventions by analyzing existing code patterns

prompt_templates.title: Quick Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the code in the project for style consistency. Check naming conventions, formatting, and organization patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Convention Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the codebase to identify existing style conventions. Look at naming, file structure, and formatting patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Style Fixes
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate specific style recommendations for improving code consistency. Include before and after examples.

prompt_templates.title: Tool Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend linting and formatting tools that match the project's existing style conventions.

output_examples.input: Review the JavaScript files for style consistency
output: Naming patterns: Functions use camelCase with verb prefixes (fetchUser, calculateTotal)
Issue found: Mixed use of 'status' and 'isStatus' boolean naming
Formatting: 2-space indent detected in all files
Import organization inconsistent - group by type
Recommended: Use Prettier with existing ESLint config

best_practices: Follow existing patterns even when not ideal for consistency
Use automated tools to enforce style in CI/CD pipelines
anti_patterns: Mixing different naming conventions in the same file
Inconsistent error handling patterns across functions

faq.question: Which languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Ruby, Go, Java, C++, Rust, PHP, Swift, Kotlin and other common languages.

faq.question: What style issues can it detect?
faq.answer: Naming conventions, indentation, line length, import ordering, comment styles, and code organization patterns.

faq.question: Does it integrate with existing linters?
faq.answer: It reads linter configurations and suggests tools but does not install or configure them automatically.

faq.question: Is my code data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only reads code for analysis. No code is sent anywhere or modified without user approval.

faq.question: Why use this over standard linters?
faq.answer: Linters enforce syntax rules. This skill catches project-specific conventions, naming patterns, and style issues that linters miss.

faq.question: How is this different from Prettier?
faq.answer: Prettier formats code automatically. This skill analyzes patterns, explains issues, and recommends solutions with context.
